A student is required to draw a perfect four-line chart showing the relationship between the number of objects a plane encounters on a particular flight, and all of the objects along its path.  If a plane has 12 objects on its path, how many does it encounter along its path?
Output:  40

To solve this question, the student should use:
1. A diagram to show the relationship between the number (or height of the objects) the plane encounters while moving through its path, and all of the total objects along the path to calculate the number that it encounters along its path.
2. An equation to prove that the total number of objects is greater than 12.
3. A graphing function to graph the relationship between the number encountered along the plane's path, and the total number of objects it encounters along its path, and to calculate the total number of number of objects between the plane and each object.

1) Take two paperclips, a long piece of wire and some packing tape, cut a hole and stuff the paperclips into the hole to create an air tight seal. Then, take out the stuffing tape. Press your hands into the holes very lightly and work in little circles. You can feel the air moving. This is your air pressure gauge. Hold the paperclips in this position for three minutes.
To check and see if your air pressure is safe, place your finger in your closed thumb. If the air feels tight, there is enough air in the tube to keep your finger moist and moist enough not to melt the packing tape.

2) Now remove the packing tape and look at your air tube. It should be about one-half inch (inch) long, about one-third (3/4) inch (1 inch) deep and about one-third inch (1 inch) wide. Now it is time to check the valve. Now remove the cap from the air tube. In the cap you will see a small valve, one inch in diameter and one-halfinch in the center. Use the two small round end of the cap and pinch the valve in place against the rim of your tube until it is sealed tight. Check the outside of the tube against your finger and feel for pressure (see 1).
Now check the inside face of the tube against your wrist and feel for pressure. It should be a small amount of pressure at this position.

Your gauge for air pressure is good.

3) Take another paperclip now and this time use only 2 ends of the clip and a single round end. Push the air out of your hand. Check on the outside and inside of the tube. You should still be able to feel the air moving slightly. This is a pressure gauge.

4) Using a magnifying glass and some tape, measure two paperclips next to each other. You can now feel the air moving through the tube. This is a resistance gauge. Your air pump requires some resistance to help air pump.

5) Next, take another sharpie marker and mark the outside face of the air pressure tube for each time you filled or emptied your tube. Assignment Code: ABO

Assumptions:

1. This problem is posed as a hypothetical situation.

2. It is taught by the senior teacher in the band.

3. Students know that the senior teacher is a good band teacher. This is reinforced by the teacher's comments during the lesson, such as "A band teacher is supposed to be a leader and set an example for his or her students."

4. Students know that the teacher does not have a favorite instrument.

5. Students are told to "think about some question that only your teacher would know the answer to."

6. Students should not expect to learn much about the band from their music teacher.

7. Students should expect a high level of intellectual challenge in a band theory lesson.

8. Assignments for this assignment would be given to students on Monday morning.

The teacher uses the method of "assumptions made, questions asked, and answers given" to teach this problem. As such, students in this class might:

1. Be skeptical when the senior teacher's answers are too vague or too precise and expect more.

2. Expect too much intellectual challenge.

3. Expect to ask more questions about the instrument assignments and have it be answered in a short time frame.

4. Be a lot more critical of how the teacher plans to teach the lesson.

5. Ask questions and/or try to be different from the regular student by asking the teacher questions about the instrument assignments.

A

Input: There were 2 men. Henry was in the passenger seat, and Bill was in the driver seat. They drove across the state of Alabama together, and Henry arrived at a town called Birmingham. The first shop that they entered had a sign that read “No black men inside.” So, Henry asked the woman who answered the door if they had a black man inside. Then, without leaving his car, Bill drove off and pulled into a nearby parking garage. Two or three people stopped to ask him about the sign at the garage door. “This garage is always so empty,” one woman said to Henry. Henry replied, “You’re right, and that’s because we don’t come around here much.” When he got out of his car, Henry told Bill that he would like to take Bill shopping with him. That night, he returned to the woman’s garage and opened the door so that Bill could enter. That was the first time that Bill had ever been refused admission to shop somewhere simply because he was black. When they reached the clothing shop, Bill asked the man at the counter to tell the cashier that he wanted to buy some clothes for a friend. They found some clothes that fit him well, and they hurried him inside, so he would not have to wait longer than 10 minutes. The woman at the counter took great pride in the fact that she had been the first person to allow a black man in her store, and that she always took the same care to do so. As she looked up in surprise from doing her final checkout, Bill said, “Hey, that was the first time that I had ever been refused any kind of service since I had been born. You took such good care of me and my friend here. So thank you!” The woman at the counter smiled, and said cheerfully, “There’s something I could do to repay you, if you would like.” Bill said, “Well, that’s just great! If you were a policeman and you came in to arrest me and the only black man in this shop was me, you would make it easy for me by having that clerk call you a name like ‘Nigger.’ But what would you like me to tell you? If you were a nurse and you came into my bed and you were having an especially bad day, would you want me to call you �

The teacher who wrote this lesson:

Answers below were chosen based upon students responses to the first question.

I had the boys choose a number as much as 80 times the number of girls to choose all together.

Students first had to identify every member of the class, which took about 5-7 seconds.

Students answered correctly one of the following: "Cathy", "Cathy", "Susan", "Susan".

After answering correctly, students were required to fill in every possible line from the answer key to the correct answer in the column on the left.

Students were instructed to fill all the correct spaces in the columns with the correct answers so we would know all possible values.

Students then filled in all of the answer keys.

Then we had them write the "What if" statements and compare their answers with the answer key, which looked close, so we decided to put the answer key on top of the table.

So students had to write the words "What If" starting with numbers up to 20 if they chose the 1st column, and up to 10 if they chose the last column.

Then they had to answer each correct answer using their "What if" statements, starting with the answer with the largest number.

Then students wrote each answer as a thought.

Finally we had them write their question on top of the table and had them select what they thought was the correct answer.

The teacher then had them write their comment to the teacher and gave it credit for the correct answer.
This is a great lesson, you have to really watch them to make sure they answer the questions properly

If you don't know how to use this, you can see the video clip I made from this lesson.

He said it was not until after he had eaten his meal and drank the water that he noticed a uniformed uniform standing outside the building. The two Germans said they were on a pilgrimage and had come to the village because it reminded them of home. Output: 38
